data.text:
ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ Canada 3-1 Sweden ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª

World Junior Championship Gold Medal Game

KeyBank Center, Buffalo ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Friday, 05 January 2018

Tyler Steenbergen scored the biggest goal of his life, and Canada won the Gold medal by defeating Sweden 3-1.

Steenbergen had played just 3:17 through two periods, had but four shots in the entire tournament, and had yet to score. In two days heâ€™ll turn 20, so he can consider this an early birthday present of the highest quality.

The goal couldnâ€™t have happened without Drake Bathersonâ€™s determined forecheck. His tenacity produced a turnover that led to a superb slap-pass from the point by Connor Timmins. It was deflected in front by Steenbergen, breaking a 1-1 tie and sending Canada on to World Junior Gold for the first time since 2015.

â€œI just about blacked out when it happened,â€ Steenbergen enthused after. â€œIâ€™m at a loss for words. And to win it for all the crowd that came out for us was pretty special.â€

â€œThey made a perfect pass to the player off to the side,â€ Sweden goalie Filip Gustavsson described. â€œWe missed that guy, and he directed it into the goal. I donâ€™t know what I could have done differently.â€

The win provided a double dose of revenge. One, for erasing terrible memories of the 2011 Gold medal game in Buffalo when the team blew a 3-0 lead in the third period. And two, for erasing more recent memories of a heart-breaking shootout loss to the United States last year in the finals.

Seven players from 2017 won Gold tonight: Carter Hart, Dillon DubÃ©, Jake Bean, Kale Clague, Dante Fabbro, Michael McLeod, and Taylor Raddysh. As well, coach Dominique Ducharme was there last year, victorious tonight.

â€œThe longer the game went, the more our speed was working and the better we were playing,â€ Ducharme said. â€œTyler had a little bit of jump tonight, so I used him more. It worked out pretty well.â€

â€œComing into this tournament, there was a job that needed to be finished,â€ said winning goalie Carter Hart, who was named player of the game for Canada. â€œApproaching this game today, we approached it with the right mindset. We wanted to make the most of our opportunity.â€

Canada won despite going 0-for-6 on the power play, which had been its forte all tournament. But the Swedes clearly did their homework before the game and not only neutralized the potent power play but scored short-handed as well.

â€œWe didnâ€™t focus too much on not scoring on the power play,â€ defenceman Cale Makar said. â€œI think the main thing is we got the win. Obviously, it would have been nice to capitalize on some of those chances, and we gave up a short-handed one, but in the end it didnâ€™t matter.â€

â€œI think everybody just trusted each other,â€ Makar continued. â€œWe knew that even if the power play wasnâ€™t clicking, we could still capitalize five-on-five. I guess thatâ€™s how we did it tonight.â€

On the other side of the ledger, Canada did not incur a penalty for the last 51 minutes of the game. In all, Sweden had 22 PIMs to Canadaâ€™s 2 (10 of the former going to Oskar Steen for a last-minute misconduct).

For Sweden, the disappointment is bitter. It hadnâ€™t won gold since 2012 and finished runner-up in the Bronze medal game for the last three years.

â€œThereâ€™s disappointment as a group that we lost the game,â€ said Timothy Liljegren. â€œBut Iâ€™m really proud of all the guys. There were a lot of guys who played with injuries. We gave 100 per cent. We donâ€™t regret anything. Itâ€™s all about honour and pride. We just wanted to go out there and play 100 per cent and show all the fans watching in Sweden that weâ€™re a good hockey team.â€

Lias Andersson, upset by the loss, threw his Silver medal in the stands. â€œI didnâ€™t want it,â€ he said. â€œThe guy in the stands wanted it more than me, so I gave it to him.â€

The first period proved that you donâ€™t need goals for exciting hockey; you need only skilled players moving freely up and down the ice.

The Swedes didnâ€™t get the start they wanted, though. Without doubt, the first thing on coach Tomas Montenâ€™s checklist of what not to do was to not take penalties. Canada had converted on nearly 60 per cent of all power plays through the first six games, and this was an aspect of the game that might well have decided gold.

That being said, just 3:46 after the opening faceoff, Gustav LindstrÃ¶m took an interference penalty. Although Canada had a couple of good chances, Gustavsson stood tall and the danger was averted.

A little later, the Swedes got a power play of their own, to no great effect. The Swedes had more shots in the firstâ€”16-9â€”but Canada had as many decent scoring chances. Both goalies were steady and letter perfect.

Not so in the second. Canada opened the scoring just 1:49 into the period on a couple of great plays by Jordan Kyrou and Dillon DubÃ©. Kyrou brought the puck up ice and slid a nice pass straight ahead to DubÃ©, who was covered by Timothy Liljegren.

DubÃ© managed to fight off the check, control the puck, and then snap a shot over the glove of a surprised Gustavsson, thrilling the massive Canadian crowd of 17,544.

That got both teams going, but the Swedes in particular stepped it up a notch. Defenceman Rasmus Dahlin made several fine rushes, creating some good scoring chances, but Hart was rock solid and square to the shooter on every puck that went his way.

But when Canada went to the power play later in the period, Sweden struck back. Canadaâ€™s Robert Thomas pinched at the Sweden blue line and Linus LindstrÃ¶m and Tim SÃ¶derlund bolted up ice on a two-on-two. They criss-crossed inside the Canadian blue line, and SÃ¶derlund wired a high shot short side off the post and in at 13:07 to tie the game.

It was Swedenâ€™s third short-handed goal in its last three periods of hockey.

As the third period progressed, shifts got shorter and players more cautious, but there were still moments of offence in what felt like an overtime period. Sweden won a faceoff in the Canadian end, and defenceman Jesper Sellgren ripped a shot off the post behind Hart.

â€œAny time youâ€™re in a game of this magnitude and the score is so close, you get a little cautious. But both teams were pressing a bit as well. We didnâ€™t want to go to overtime,â€ Makar said.

A short time later, Boris Katchouk snapped a shot off Gustavssonâ€™s shoulder that would have gone in but for the fine save.

Canada came perilously close to winning in regulation on its last power play when Taylor Raddysh tipped a shot off the post, but the puck stayed out, setting the stage for Steenbergenâ€™s heroics.

Alex Formenton salted the win with an empty netter 36 seconds later.

â€œEveryone was just going nuts,â€ said Thomas. â€œThereâ€™s not really words to describe it. We were all just so happy for each other. We fought hard and we had a helluva game. It was something special that Iâ€™ll remember forever.â€
